name: Tokyo
intro_vibe: The Electric Capital: Where ancient tradition meets neon-lit future.

general_info.description: Tokyo is the capital of Japan and the world's most populous metropolitan area. A city of contrasts, Tokyo seamlessly blends ancient temples with skyscrapers, traditional tea ceremonies with cutting-edge technology, and serene gardens with the chaotic energy of Shibuya Crossing. But beyond the sights, it is a high-efficiency operating system defined by rigid unwritten protocols ('Meiwaku' or avoiding nuisance) and complex logistical flows.

etiquette_tips: The 'Meiwaku' Rule: The golden rule of Tokyo is 'Meiwaku'—avoiding nuisance to others. This explains why trains are silent and backpacks are worn on the front. It is not just politeness; it is infrastructure.
Silence is Social Glue: Noise creates social friction. Talking on the phone on the train is a major taboo. Conversations should be hushed. Silence is an active behavior to respect shared space.
The Trash Reality: There are NO public trash cans (a legacy of 1995 security measures). You must carry your trash with you until you find a bin at a convenience store (konbini) or your hotel.
Tabearuki (No Eating While Walking): Walking while eating is frowned upon ('sloppy'). If you buy street food, stand near the shop to eat it, dispose of trash there, and then move on.
Queue Culture: Lining up is sacred. Whether it's for the train or a restaurant, never cut the line. If there's a queue, the food is probably worth it.
Cash vs Card: While modernizing, many Ramen shops, ticket machines, and temples are still CASH ONLY. Always carry 10,000 Yen in cash.
Escalator Sides: Stand on the LEFT, walk on the RIGHT. This is rigidly enforced by peer pressure. (Note: This swaps in Osaka).

Procedural Politeness: Japanese politeness is about correctness and efficiency, not emotional warmth. A lack of smiles doesn't mean they are rude; it means they are focused on doing their job perfectly.
No Tipping: Excellent service is standard. Tipping causes confusion and may be returned to you as 'lost money'.
Shoes Off: Look for the entryway step (genkan). If there are slippers, use them. Never wear toilet slippers outside the bathroom.

essential_phrases.local: ありがとうございます (Arigatou gozaimasu)

essential_phrases.note: The ultimate multi-tool word. Use it to call a waiter, apologize, or say thanks. It implies 'I am sorry for the trouble'.
Use this only for personal mistakes/apologies.

essential_phrases.local: お会計お願いします (Okaikei onegaishimasu)

neighborhoods.name: Shibuya
neighborhoods.description: The beating heart of Tokyo's youth culture. Defined by verticality and valley topography. The station is a stack; the Ginza line is on the 3rd floor, others are deep underground. Use 'Urban Cores' (elevators) to move up.

neighborhoods.name: Shinjuku
neighborhoods.description: Tokyo's busiest district and transport hub. Navigate by cardinal direction: East Gate = Neon/Noise (Kabukicho). West Gate = Verticality/Business (Skyscrapers). South Gate = Shopping/Open Air.

neighborhoods.name: Asakusa
neighborhoods.description: Old Tokyo preserved. Historic temples, traditional shops, and the nostalgic atmosphere of Edo-era Japan. Visit early (6am) or late (8pm) to avoid the crush.

neighborhoods.name: Shimokitazawa
neighborhoods.description: The hipster capital. Narrow pedestrian streets packed with vintage clothing stores, vinyl shops, cafes, and small theaters. Check out the new 'Bonus Track' greenway connecting to Setagaya-Daita.

neighborhoods.name: Yanaka
neighborhoods.description: A rare survivor of WWII bombings. Low-rise buildings, many temples, and a distinct residential vibe. Walk the 'Yanesen' route from Ueno to Nippori for a glimpse of pre-war Tokyo.

neighborhoods.name: Daikanyama & Ebisu
neighborhoods.description: The 'Brooklyn of Tokyo'. Stylish, expensive, and residential. Home to T-Site bookstore and riverside walks. This is where fashionable Tokyoites spend their weekends.

neighborhoods.name: Koenji
neighborhoods.description: Raw, lived-in, and famous for its punk rock roots and vintage culture. A great place to experience 'everyday' Tokyo life away from the glitz.

logistics.title: Local Survival Tips
logistics.summary: Essential friction-removers for a smooth trip.
details: Station Shock: Major stations are mini-cities. Exiting the wrong side (e.g., East vs West in Shinjuku) puts you 20 mins away. Check exit numbers carefully.
Last Train Protocol: Trains stop between 23:30-00:30. 'Last Train' often means to the terminal, not *your* station. Missing it means a $50+ taxi or a Manga Cafe stay.
Rush Hour: Avoid trains 7:30am-9:00am. It is physical crush capacity. Silence is mandatory.
Luggage Forwarding (Takkyubin): Don't haul bags on trains. Send luggage from the airport to your hotel for ~$20. Look for the 'Black Cat' logo.

logistics.title: Getting Around
logistics.summary: Tokyo's train system is legendary. Clean, punctual, and covers everywhere.
details: JR Yamanote Line: The green circular line connecting major hubs (Shibuya, Shinjuku, Tokyo).
Tokyo Metro: 13 subway lines. Google Maps is essential for navigating transfers.
Google Maps: The only navigation app you need. It tells you exactly which car to ride for the fastest exit.

IC Card Reality (2025): Physical Suica cards are scarce due to chip shortages. Use 'Mobile Suica' on iPhone (add to Apple Wallet, charge with Mastercard/Amex) or buy a 'Welcome Suica' tourist card at the airport.

logistics.title: Money & Wifi
logistics.summary: Cash is King. Wifi is spotty.
details: Cash Rule: Always carry ¥20,000. Many ramen shops and ticket machines are still cash-only.
7-Eleven ATMs: The most reliable for foreign cards. 24/7.
Connectivity: Public Wifi is unreliable. Pre-arrange an eSIM or Pocket Wifi. Navigation without live data is impossible.

logistics.title: Scams to Avoid
logistics.summary: Tokyo is extremely safe, but avoid 'Touts'.
details: The Tout Rule: NEVER follow a street promoter in Kabukicho or Roppongi. The script is 'Massages?' or 'Cheap drink?'. You will be spiked and drained of thousands.
Fake Monks: Do not accept 'golden cards' or blessings from monks on the street who demand cash.
'Girl' Bars: Avoid places where staff stand outside aggressively pulling you in.
Defense: Ignore them completely. Do not say 'maybe later'. Walk with purpose.

logistics.title: Apps to Download
logistics.summary: These apps will make Tokyo navigation seamless.
details: Google Maps: Essential for train routes.
Google Translate: Use the camera feature to read menus.
Suica (Apple Wallet): Add a transit card directly to your iPhone.
Tabelog: The Japanese 'Yelp'. 3.5 stars is a very high score here.

must_eat.description: Fresh fish over vinegared rice. From high-end Omakase to budget-friendly Kaiten-zushi (conveyor belt). Don't mix wasabi into your soy sauce.
Tokyo's soul food. Rich broth, springy noodles, and toppings. Slurping is encouraged—it cools the noodles and enhances flavor. Order via ticket machine.
Thick, mild, and addictive. Completely different from Indian or Thai curry. Served with rice and often a pork cutlet (Katsu Curry). Go to CoCo Ichibanya to try it.
Breaded, deep-fried pork cutlet. Crisp, juicy, and surgically precise. Served with shredded cabbage, rice, and miso soup. A comfort food perfection.
Grilled chicken skewers cooked over charcoal. Not just breast meat—try skin (kawa), thigh (momo), and meatballs (tsukune). The quintessential after-work food paired with beer.
Thinly sliced beef and onions simmered in soy broth over rice. Fast, cheap (¥500), and available 24/7 at chains like Yoshinoya or Sukiya. The local fast food.
7-Eleven, Lawson, FamilyMart. The food quality is shockingly high. Try the Egg Salad Sandwich, Onigiri (rice balls), and Famichiki (fried chicken).
Thick wheat noodles (Udon) or thin buckwheat noodles (Soba). Cheap, fast, and slurped standing up at train station counters.
The real lunch of Tokyo. A balanced tray with a main (grilled fish, ginger pork, karaage), rice, miso soup, and pickles. Fast, healthy, and served at chains like Ootoya or Yayoiken.
Tokyo's social release valve. Note the 'Otoshi': a mandatory table charge (¥300-500) that comes with a small appetizer. It is not a scam; it is the cover charge. Shout 'Sumimasen!' to order.
Don't look for eggs and toast. The local breakfast is either a traditional set (rice, fish) or a convenience store pastry. Cafes opening before 10am are rare.
Located in basements of department stores (Isetan, Mitsukoshi). A wonderland of high-end bento, sweets, and gifts. Go at 7:30pm for the discount rush. Great for hotel room picnics.
Standing bars for salarymen. Cheap, loud, and social. Often Cash-on-Delivery (COD), making them scam-proof and authentic. Try Shimbashi or Ueno.

items.description: Tokyo's oldest and most famous temple. Walk through the giant lantern gate and the Nakamise shopping street.
A serene forest in the middle of the city. Dedicated to Emperor Meiji. A peaceful escape from the Harajuku crowds next door.

items.name_local: 渋谷スクランブル交差点
items.description: The world's busiest pedestrian crossing. Organized chaos. Best viewed from the Mag's Park rooftop or Starbucks.
The hipster neighborhood. Vintage clothing, vinyl records, and indie cafes. No skyscrapers here, just vibes.
The best FREE view in Tokyo. See Mt. Fuji on a clear day. Less crowded than Shibuya Sky or Skytree. Located in West Shinjuku.
Massive traditional garden. A perfect reset button when the city gets too loud. Famous for cherry blossoms.
The neon soul of Tokyo. Wander Omoide Yokocho (Piss Alley) for smoky yakitori, or just walk the streets to feel the cyberpunk energy.
A cluster of over 200 tiny bars (seating 4-6 people) packed into narrow alleys. A relic of post-war Tokyo. Cover charges apply.
Immersive digital art where you walk barefoot through water and crystal lights. Extremely popular—book weeks in advance.
The center of Anime and Otaku culture. Arcades, maid cafes, and towering electronics stores.
Traditional covered shopping arcades found in every neighborhood. No big brands, just local butchers, tea shops, and cheap croquette stands. This is where real life happens.

affiliate_products.title: Japan Travel Adapter (Type A/B)
affiliate_products.reason: Japan uses Type A (two flat pins). European/UK travelers need an adapter.

affiliate_products.title: Pocket WiFi / eSIM
affiliate_products.reason: Free WiFi is rare in public. You need data for Google Maps and translation. Rent a Pocket WiFi or buy an eSIM.

affiliate_products.title: Coin Purse
affiliate_products.reason: Cash is still king, and you will accumulate a LOT of coins. A dedicated coin purse is a life-saver.
